title: How to Get Over the Fear of Creating Thought Leadership Content
description: A few mindset shifts and tactics to help you overcome your fear of creating thought leadership content.
content: Si Quan Ong Content marketer @ Ahrefs. I've been in digital marketing for the past 6 years and have spoken at some of the industryâ€™s largest conferences in Asia (TIECon and Digital Marketing Skill Share.) I also write about my curiosities on my Substack. Get the week's best marketing content Email Subscription Subscribe Leave this field empty if you're human: Contents Five years ago, I published a study where we investigated 3.6 million domains to find out if Squarespace was great for SEO.Hereâ€™s the thing: We previously ran the exact same study for Wix and it did well. So we decided to replicate it for Squarespace.Quite innocuous, right? Turns out it wasnâ€™t. Someone shared the takeaways from that post on Reddit and boy, was the criticism full on.Call me thin-skinned, but I remember feeling hurt. It was my first ever â€˜researchâ€™ article, after all. And it was as safe a research study as possible. But reality is often harsher than youâ€™d imagine.Criticism doesnâ€™t diminish. Five years later, I still see the same about the studies I publish:The reason why Iâ€™m telling these stories is because making thought leadership contentâ€”studies, opinions, experimentsâ€”can be scary. Criticism will come hard and fast. Youâ€™ll put yourself out there and can expect to receive â€˜hateâ€™.Iâ€™d admit thatâ€™s one reason why I (used to) love making SEO content. Use a couple of SEO tools, pop in the necessary H2s (What is X? Why is X important? How to do X?), and fill in the blanks. No opinion required. Publish a post and tuck yourself in bed, warm and cozy.But itâ€™s only a matter of time that it wonâ€™t work anymore. Weâ€™ve avoided years of controversy as content marketers by shuffling ideas around. Content curation is safe because it canâ€™t offend anyone. But generative AI can do that regurgitation now. And it can do that better than all of usâ€¦ and at scale too.If we want to stand out in our careers and help the companies we work for differentiate from others, we need to embrace creating thought leadership content. Sharing lived experiences, professing strong opinions, and gaining and using our hard-earned expertise.Doing that first requires us to overcome that fear of putting ourselves out there.ContentsEmbrace polarisation because it means people careâ€œThe best art divides the audience, where if you put out a record, and half the people who hear it absolutely love it, and half the people who hear it absolutely hate it, youâ€™ve done well because itâ€™s pushing that boundary. If everyone thinks, oh thatâ€™s pretty good, why bother making it? It doesnâ€™t mean as much.â€Rick Rubin, Record executive and producerThe brutal truth about making thought leadership content is that youâ€™ll overestimate yourself. Most of the time, no one cares.Iâ€™ve published hundreds of blog posts but could only summon hate for two. Because no one cares about the rest. It didnâ€™t challenge anyoneâ€™s thinking or was about topics that no one bothered about.So, if you published something that other people actually took the time to criticize, it means you did a good job. You pushed the boundaries and challenged the industryâ€™s assumptions. You made people think.Itâ€™s a mindset shift. You donâ€™t need to fear criticism anymore. It can still hurt of course, but take pride in the fact that youâ€™ve made people notice.But donâ€™t take this to say you should intentionally poke bears. Your goal is not to say something controversial â€œfor the attentionâ€. Donâ€™t ragebait and donâ€™t rile people up. Thatâ€™s not helpful and itâ€™s not thought leadership content.You should share your genuine opinions based on your expertise or experience. Sometimes, this polarises because it differs from everyone elseâ€™s. But youâ€™ll be surprised how many people were thinking about it.For example, I was a little hesitant to publish my opinion about entity SEO. After all, who am I to talk about it? But I plucked up my courage. Turns out: There are people who agree!Further readingWes Kao â€” ğŸŒµ Spiky point of view: Letâ€™s get a little controversialFearlessly share your opinions because youâ€™re doing others a serviceImagine if Ryan, our Director of Content Marketing, didnâ€™t share his thoughts about generative AI and content marketing. It would be doing everyone a disservice because many people would continue to try and generate as much AI content as possible to rank in the SERPs.That would damage the SEO and content marketing industry:More AI content means poorer search results and quality. Everyone is worse off for it.AI content is mediocre and will likely lead to inferior content marketing ROI. Low ROI means less investment from stakeholders, affecting the industry.Iâ€™m not saying Ryan is that influential. (He might be, though.) But if he could change the minds of one, ten, or even a hundred peopleâ€”thatâ€™s a big impact. He helped everyone do things better and improved the industry as a whole.Imagine that was you, but out of fear, you neglected to share your opinion on the right ways to do something in your industry. Now, everyone in your industry will continue to chug along the wrong path without any improvements. You did everyone a disservice.But what if you did the opposite and shared your opinion? You could positively impact everyone in your industry.Welcome pushback because it contributes to better thinkingScientists publish their results or opinions in publications. Other scientists can read, debate, and *gasp*, criticize it. Thatâ€™s the nature of science and itâ€™s how science progresses.You can think of your thought leadership content as the same. You canâ€™t sharpen your thinking if it stays in your head. Publishing the ideas that come from your observations, lived experience, experiments, or expertise allows others to poke holes in your logic or strengthen your arguments.For example, when I published my opinion on entity SEO, I got experienced SEOs disagreeing with my take:And that is awesome! I ended up learning so much more about the topic. That wouldnâ€™t have been possible if I didnâ€™t hit publish.I didnâ€™t know anything about the entities-attributes-variables (EAV) model previously, but now I have a lead to investigate further. I could even hop on a call with Lazarina to learn more. I might even change my mind about the whole thing!And who knows, I might end up writing an entirely new article about how entity SEO is the future.Strengthen your content by steelmanning your arguments before publishingOne reason you might be afraid of publishing thought leadership content is because youâ€™re unsure if your logic is sound or your arguments watertight.If thatâ€™s your concern, then steelman your arguments before publishing. Steelmanning is the practice of addressing the strongest form of your â€œopponentâ€™sâ€ argument. If you can argue against the steelman, your position will be stronger.In fact, it was the advice Ryan gave me before I started drafting my â€œentity SEOâ€ post:Thatâ€™s what I did. Before I wrote anything, I hopped on a call with my colleague Louise to discuss if my â€œopinionâ€ had merit:Then, after I had drafted the outline, I asked my colleague Despina to review it:Doing all of that gave me confidence that my opinion was worth publishing.Define your fears by running a fear-setting exerciseEvery quarter, Tim Ferriss runs an exercise he calls â€œfear-settingâ€. The basic idea is to define your fears in writing.Hereâ€™s the question he uses:â€œDefine your nightmare, the absolute worst that could happen if you did what you are considering. What doubt, fears, and â€œwhat-ifsâ€ pop up as you consider the big changes you canâ€”or needâ€”to make? Envision them in painstaking detail. Would it be the end of your life? What would be the permanent impact, if any, on a scale of 1â€“10? Are these things really permanent? How likely do you think it is that they would actually happen?â€Tim Ferriss, Author and podcaster, Tim Ferriss ShowWhatâ€™s the worst that could happen? Someone already said my work was no better than a second-grade kid. But Iâ€™m still here, publishing thought leadership content and sharing my opinion.Often, youâ€™ll find that thereâ€™s nothing really worth worrying about.Respond to existing ideas by using â€œyes, andâ€Thought leadership content doesnâ€™t always mean contradicting the mainstream. You can also help signal boost other peopleâ€™s ideas.In his thought leadership content course, Ryan suggests overcoming the fear of thought leadership by responding to an existing idea. Youâ€™d want to collect opinions you agree with from forums or social media, and then add additional ideas to the discussion. For example, you could show how to execute the strategy, elaborate on the idea, or reveal that itâ€™s related to another idea.I used â€œyes, andâ€ when I wrote my post on white hat link building. Instead of compiling every potential link-building tactic, I â€˜respondedâ€™ to an existing idea by showing how to execute the ones featured in an industry-wide survey.Final thoughtsEach piece of published thought leadership content makes the next one easierâ€”but only slightly. I still hesitate every time I write a piece, knowing I could be judged, criticized, or ridiculed.But as Tim Ferriss writes,â€œA personâ€™s success in life can be measured by the number of uncomfortable conversations he or she is willing to have.â€This uncomfortable conversation could be one with your inner fear. Or it could be one with other professionals who will comment on your work. But if you can overcome all of that, it will only serve you better.
